Appearance
From Wiktionary, the free dictionary

English

[edit]

Alternative forms

[edit]
  • savorer (US)

Etymology

[edit]

From savour +‎ -er.

Noun

[edit]

savourer (plural savourers)

  1. One who savours or smacks of something; one who favours or takes pleasure in something.

References

[edit]
  • William Dwight Whitney, Benjamin E[li] Smith, editors (1911), “savourer”, in The Century Dictionary […], New York, N.Y.: The Century Co., →OCLC.

French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Inherited from Old French savourer, from savour. Compare with the noun saveur.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /sa.vu.ʁe/
  • Audio:(file)
  • Audio (Switzerland (Valais)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Paris)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Toulouse)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Vosges)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Massy)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Somain)):(file)

Verb

[edit]

savourer

  1. to savour, to savor
  2. to taste

1 The French gerund is usable only with the preposition en.
2 In less formal writing or speech, these tenses may be found to have been replaced in the following way:
past historic → present perfect
past anterior → pluperfect
imperfect subjunctive → present subjunctive
pluperfect subjunctive → past subjunctive

(Christopher Kendris [1995], Master the Basics: French, pp. 77, 78, 79, 81).

Further reading

[edit]
  • “savourer”, in Trésor de la langue française informatisé [Digitized Treasury of the French Language], 2012.

Anagrams

[edit]
  • ouvreras

Old French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From savour.

Verb

[edit]

savourer

  1. to give taste (to)
    • (Can we date this quote?), Olivier de Serres
      Au semer des melons, aucuns ajoustent les bonnes senteurs et liqueurs pour en odorer et savourer le fruit.
      (please add an English translation of this quotation)

Conjugation

[edit]

This verb conjugates as a first-group verb ending in -er. This verb has a stressed present stem saveur distinct from the unstressed stem savour. Old French conjugation varies significantly by date and by region. The following conjugation should be treated as a guide.

    Conjugation of savourer (see also Appendix:Old French verbs)
simple compound
infinitive savourer avoir savouré
gerund en savourant gerund of avoir + past participle
present participle savourant
past participle savouré
person singular plural
first second third first second third
indicative jo tu il nos vos il
simple
tenses 		present saveur saveures saveure savourons savourez saveurent
imperfect savouroie, savoureie, savouroe, savoureve savouroies, savoureies, savouroes, savoureves savouroit, savoureit, savourot, savoureve savouriiens, savouriens savouriiez, savouriez savouroient, savoureient, savouroent, savourevent
preterite savourai savouras savoura savourames savourastes savourerent
future savourerai savoureras savourera savourerons savoureroiz, savourereiz, savourerez savoureront
conditional savoureroie, savourereie savoureroies, savourereies savoureroit, savourereit savoureriiens, savoureriens savoureriiez, savoureriez savoureroient, savourereient
compound
tenses 		present perfect present tense of avoir + past participle
pluperfect imperfect tense of avoir + past participle
past anterior preterite tense of avoir + past participle
future perfect future tense of avoir + past participle
conditional perfect conditional tense of avoir + past participle
subjunctive que jo que tu qu’il que nos que vos qu’il
simple
tenses 		present saveur saveurs saveurt savourons savourez saveurent
imperfect savourasse savourasses savourast savourissons, savourissiens savourissoiz, savourissez, savourissiez savourassent
compound
tenses 		past present subjunctive of avoir + past participle

— saveure — savourons savourez —

Descendants

[edit]
  • French: savourer
  • → Middle English: savouren
    • English: savour, savor
